passage_text: Furthermore, range in pay is narrow, with salaries starting at $18K and quickly nearing the top at only $26K. Workers at Fifth Third Bancorp, Federal Credit Union, and U.S. Bank also face smaller salaries than the rest of the field — average earnings for these employers come to $21K, $22K, and $22K respectively.

Teller Salary Range. Bank tellers make up approximately 90 percent of all tellers nationwide. The average teller in all industries had the same 2011 hourly wage as a bank teller, $12.27 per hour, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Teller wages at the 10th percentile were $9.30 per hour or $19,350 per year.
Average Bank Teller salaries for job postings in Pennsylvania are 4% lower than average Bank Teller salaries for job postings nationwide.

The estimated salary of a bank teller depends in part on location. Three states paid tellers in all industries more than $28,000 per year on average in 2011, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Alaska had the highest annual pay of $29,630 for a full-time teller, followed by Connecticut, at $28,900.

The average compensation for a bank teller in the United States in September 2014 was $10.44 per hour. This figure was based on the combined results of nearly 8,000 individuals, whose hourly pay rates varied between $8.39 and $13.21. Overtime rates fell between $10.48 and $20.05 per hour.

For example the median expected annual pay for a typical Teller I in the United States is $24,215, so 50% of the people who perform the job of Teller I in the United States are expected to make less than $24,215.

The average Bank Teller in the United States can expect to rake in roughly $10.76 per hour. Overall incomes of Bank Tellers — including $1K bonuses, $3K profit sharing proceeds, and $2K commissions on the more lucrative end — generally ranges between $18K and $30K.
Average Bank Teller salaries for job postings nationwide are 59% lower than average salaries for all job postings nationwide.
